content:
sfhowes 提道
Disable account hub in Settings/General, then add the account from ≡ - New Account - Email (which includes a manual.config. option).

在「設定 > 一般 > 帳號中心（實驗中）」中，將該功能取消後，再重新點選「新增帳號」，畫面會回到最初的登入頁面，就像第一次登入時一樣。 開發人員應該注意到這個重大的問題。 In Settings > General > Account Center (Experimental), after disabling this feature and then clicking “Add Account” again, the page reverts to the original login screen, just like the first-time login. Developers should take note of this significant issue. THANKS!

content: I would like to archive emails from my numerous email accounts locally, but with each account in a separate local folder so that they are stored in different locations on my hard drive. Later, I would like to permanently archive a local folder, including removing it from Thunderbird. However, I may need to open such emails again at some point and would then like to import them back into Thunderbird.
creator: cwinkler

content: in the 'copies&folders' pane of each account, you can specify unique folder for the archiving. For the removing and later importing, you can exit thunderbird and use windows file explorer to copy elsewhere, since they are just files. Or, you can use the addon 'importexporttools NG' to do that. just highlight a folder, rightclick and select the importexport option to export mbox. At some future point that you want to read them again, just highlight Local Folders, rightclick and then select the importexport option to import mbox. yes, it's that easy. :)
creator: davidsk

content: thanks for your hint. however, I was referring to this special account called "local folder" which does not have an identity, see attached screenshots. can I have more than one of these?
creator: cwinkler

content:
There is only one Local Folders in Thunderbird, but you can have multiple subfolders. This is because Thunderbird needs a root location. If you click 'account settings' and scroll down left column to Local Folders and look at bottom line, you will see the 'Local Directory' pointer. If you want your local folders to be elsewhere than in the thunderbird profile, it's a simple process:

  1. first, create your root folder for Local Folders. It can be on same drive on another drive.
  2. once done, you can then click the account settings>Local Folders pane and change the Local Directory to point to the one you created. Thunderbird may insist on a restart before using it.
  3. Now, you have local folders separate from thunderbird and set your archive folders in separate folders there.
creator: davidsk

content: See https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/localfolder/
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thunderbird only uses one profile. For it to be receiving mail in different profiles would require that you switch between the two. My inference is that one profile is active and there are older messages in the other one. To resolve this, first confirm the active one. You can do that by clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, locate 'Profiles' in left column and then click 'about:profiles' - this will show the name of the active profile, and the inactive profile.

At this point, exit thunderbird and, using windows file explorer, COPY (not move) the folders with missing content from the inactive folder to the active folder <POPaat Mail\Local Folders IMAP accounts are not affected, but if you use POP, the POP account in inactive folder will be at Mail\<POPaccount> folder. Be sure to only copy to Mail\Local Folders for active profile . If ANY copy will overlay an existing folder, RENAME prior to copying. Now, restart thunderbird and you should see the missing data. If desired, you can now copy from these copied folders to their normal folder. TIP: We recommend always using the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder to copy to new PCs, as that guarantees not experiencing the problem you had. Here are the normal steps: <strong>BACKUP
  1. ensure thunderbird is not running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
RESTORE
  1. ensure thunderbird is installed and NOT running
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  4. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

creator: sfhowes

content:
In Windows OS > Settings > Personalisation > Colours Please check: 'Choose your mode' Select 'Custom' Make sure both windows mode and the apps mode are both set to 'dark'

In Thunderbird Settings > Composition If you select: 'Use reader's default colours' then it will use the theme colours. The options below for the Text and Background should be greyed out and unused. The prefs:

  • msgcompose.background_color
  • msgcompose.text_color

These are disregarded because you have selected 'Use reader's default colours'.

If you uncheck that option then whatever is set for Text and Background is used, but please note these options are then included in the HTML when you send. So enforced on recipients, although they may have options to override like Thunderbird.

However..... I'm testing this issue in the beta version to see what is going on. I have same settings - use Dark theme and 'Use Reader's default colours' I have not selected 'Use Paragraph format instead of Body Text by default' But if I do select it then it alters results but still not as desired - some areas which have html css code as a 'paragraph' will get black text on white background even if all other areas are applying the dark theme. So that is the weird section you see.

I see all as expected in the 'Message Pane', so that is ok (please note - just for clarity - there is no 'preview' pane and never has been. All emails seen in Message Pane are not previews, they are opened emails.)

Selecting an email which I know has HTML css code applied, so some areas maybe coloured but generally uses black on white. I'm seeing a variety of issues which are not expected. This sounds very similar to the issue you are seeing.

I'm going to create a bug report on this. I'll post a link to it.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
You can install a add-on; https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/tbkeys-lite/?src=search

After the installation in thunderbird go to the settings of tbkeys and replace the main key bindings with the following: { 

   "0": "unset",    "1": "unset",    "2": "unset",    "3": "unset",    "4": "unset",    "5": "unset",    "6": "unset",    "7": "unset",    "8": "unset",    "9": "unset",    "j": "unset",    "k": "unset",    "o": "unset",    "f": "unset",    "#": "unset",    "r": "unset",    "a": "unset",    "x": "unset",    "c": "unset",    "u": "unset",    "b": "unset",    "m": "unset",    "p": "unset",    "s": "unset",    "t": "unset",    "w": "unset",    "]": "unset",    "[": "unset"

}

this will make that all single keys don't have a shortcode. --

content: Wee can advise better if we know what it is that you want to accomplish. For example, are you wanting to move your email accounts to a new computer? Or do you just want to export some email messages, but not the accounts? Regarding POP, you may switch to IMAP, but that requires setting up a separate account; you cannot change an existing account from one to the other.
